statistics.claim: Wood interiors associated with reduced blood pressure and stress responses compared to white-painted surfaces
statistics.source: University of British Columbia / FPInnovations collaborative research

statistics.claim: Office workers in environments with wood elements reported higher satisfaction and wellbeing scores

studies.title: Wood in the Human Environment: Restorative Properties of Wood in the Built Indoor Environment
studies.finding: Physiological stress recovery was faster in rooms with wood interiors than in rooms without wood elements

studies.title: Is interior wood use psychologically beneficial? A review of psychological responses toward wood
studies.finding: Review found consistent evidence that wood interiors evoke positive emotional responses and perceived naturalness

studies.authors: Tsunetsugu, Y., Miyazaki, Y., Sato, H.
studies.title: Physiological effects in humans induced by the visual stimulation of room interiors with different wood quantities
studies.finding: Moderate wood coverage (45%) in rooms produced optimal physiological responses; both no wood and excessive wood coverage were less beneficial

notes: IMPORTANT CAVEAT: I was unable to perform live web searches to verify current sources. The evidence cited above is based on my training knowledge through early 2025. The wood/health connection is reasonably well-documented in academic literature (particularly from Japanese 'shinrin-yoku' research tradition and Canadian forestry research). However, specific statistics should be independently verified. The broader 'biophilic material palette' concept (including stone, clay, fiber) has less direct research than wood specifically. Programs and policies cited may have evolved since my knowledge cutoff. Recommend verification of all citations before use.
